awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Collaborative: Incorporating Sociotechnical Cybersecurity Learning Within Undergraduate Capstone Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
All technology professionals require basic proficiency in cybersecurity.  However, typical computing curricula do not require any courses in cybersecurity.  As a result, a majority of students graduate without any proficiency in cybersecurity relevant to the systems they will develop and use when they join the workforce.  Moreover, cybersecurity electives often cover only technical topics, and technology professionals must understand how cybersecurity is influenced by social factors.  This project will fill this curricular gap and will develop, deliver, and evaluate a suite of sociotechnical cybersecurity learning modules.  These modules can then be used in standard computing curricula to create a cybersecurity proficient software workforce that can significantly enhance cybersecurity in the workplace.

The modules will be used in capstone courses at Informatics at the University of California, Irvine (UCI) and Indiana University (IU).  The researchers will utilize the modules to create an assessment for the most critical and essential cybersecurity knowledge and skills. The outcomes of the research will advance the understanding of how students could develop sociotechnical cybersecurity proficiency as a part of their capstone experience.  Since capstones are typically a graduation requirement, integrating cybersecurity learning within these courses will have the transformative effect of all students in the computing disciplines graduating with core cybersecurity knowledge.  As a part of the research activities, several cohorts of undergraduates will receive cybersecurity training useful for their professional careers.  The learning modules and assessments will be openly available to other educators and institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This Outcomes Report is anchored in the original six objectives set for this Project, and covers how each goal was addressed or accomplished. The six objectives are:

1. Instill in CS students proficiency in the principles and foundations of important CS topics of Privacy and Cybersecurity:

This was accomplished by delivering 10-12 learning-modules to college seniors, in a college-level Capstone project, over a three- to four-year time-period.

2. Develop six learning modules on core concepts and skills in cybersecurity and privacy:

This was accomplished by developing 10-12 high-quality learning modules. During the years of COVID and remote-learning, the modules went through high-quality recording; thus they are now available as recorded videos.

3. Utilize project based learning techniques to deliver the modules in upper-division Capstone projects:

This was accomplished by delivering 10-12 learning-modules to college seniors, in a college-level Capstone project, over a three- to four-year time-period.

4. Create a set of metrics/assessment for the essential skills expected for today's cybersecurity and privacy challenges:

This was accomplished by creating a set of before/after questionnaires, and other assessments and surveys of student learning objectives.

5. Apply this assessment framework to measure the impact of our cybersecurity learning modules:

The assessment framework from goal (4) was applied to the same Capstone students, over a three- to four-year time-period.

6. Examine and compare cybersecurity properties of projects with and without our learning modules:

Steps (4) and (5) above were accomplished using known research-methods such that, for example, we compared groups of students who studied the learning modules, to control groups who did not.

We find project impactful in at least three important ways, namely (a) creating and delivering 10-12 high-quality modules of learning, now in video format, in the field of privacy and cybersecurity. (b) Engaging college seniors in multiple CS majors, in learning and applying this knowledge to their ongoing projects and, perhaps most impactful, (c) training 4-5 undergraduate REUs in research methods, data collection and data analysis, and so on.

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2024
Modified by: Hadar Ziv
